Description copied from interface: Path

replaceFirst

public Path replaceFirst(Path subpath,
                         Path replacement)
Description copied from interface: Path
Returns a path that is produced by exchanging the first occurence of the given subpath, in this path, with the given replacement. The subpath and the replacement must start and end on the same nodes respectively. There is an exception though: if the subpath lies at the start or at the end of this path, then the replacement needs not start or end and the same node respectively. Thus, in this cases the replacement can be used to create a path that either starts at a different node than this path, or ends in a different node.

If the subpath is not contained in this path, nothing happens.

Examples, assuming this path is [1-->2-->3-->4]:

  • if subpath is [2-->3], then the replacement must start on [2] and end on [3] (with whatever length)
  • if subpath is [1-->2], then the replacement path only needs to end at [2], for example this replacement is fine: [A-->B-->C-->2], which would yield: [A-->B-->C-->2-->3-->4]
  • if subpath is [3-->4], then the replacement path only needs to start at [3], for example this replacement if fine: [3-->X-->Y--Z], which would yield: [1-->2-->3-->X-->Y-->Z]

Specified by:
replaceFirst in interface Path
Returns:
a path resulted from replacing the specified subpath with the replacement

replaceAll

public Path replaceAll(Path subpath,
                       Path replacement)
Description copied from interface: Path
Returns a path that is produces by replacing every occurrence of the specified subpath in this path, by the specified replacement. The replacement's head and tail nodes must match the head and tail nodes of the subpath, respectively.

Specified by:
replaceAll in interface Path
Parameters:
subpath - the subpath occurrences of which to replace with another path
replacement - the path with which to replace all occurrences of subpath
Returns:
the resulting path
See Also:
Path.replaceFirst(Path, Path)

split

public Path[] split(int position)
Description copied from interface: Path
Splits this path at a certain point and returns the two parts. This position denotes the index of the tailNode() of the first path, and the headNode() of the second path. Valid position indexes are [0... nodeCount() - 1].

Specified by:
split in interface Path
Parameters:
position - the position of the node (getNode(position)) that the first path will end to and the second path will begin from
Returns:
an array with the two splitted paths

chechReplacementPreconditions

                                                   int end,
                                                   Path replacement)
Assumes a non-null replacement. For information about which conditions are checked here, see Path.replaceFirst(Path, Path)

See Also:
Path.replaceFirst(Path, Path)

append

public Path append(Path other)
Description copied from interface: Path
Returns a path that is produced by appending the given path at the tail of this path. The two paths must be consecutive, that is, other.headNode() == this.tailNode().

Specified by:
append in interface Path
Returns:
a path that is produced by appending the given path at the tail of this path

replace

public Path replace(int start,
                    int end,
                    Path replacement)
Description copied from interface: Path
Returns a path by replacing the specified subpath (described as a slice) with a replacement. Parameters start and end describe the head and tail node of the subpath to be replaced. Valid node indexes are [0... nodeCount() - 1]. Applying the replacement must produce a continuous path, i.e. its head and tail node must match the head and tail node of the subpath, unless either is the head or tail of this path. See Path.replaceFirst(Path, Path) for more details.

Specified by:
replace in interface Path
Parameters:
start - the index of the head node of the subpath
end - the index of the end node of the subpath
Returns:
a path by replacing the specified subpath with a replacement
See Also:
Path.replaceFirst(Path, Path)
